div.head: DRAMATIS PERSONÆ.
div.stage: [SCENE.-The royal palace in ARGOS, as in the previous tragedy. The tomb of AGAMEMNON is seen in the orchestra. ORESTES and PYLADES enter in the garb of travellers. They approach the tomb. ORESTES ascends the steps.]

div.head: CHOEPHORI.*

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: THEE, shade-escorting Hermes, I invoke,
In Hades guardian of my royal sire,—
To me, thy suppliant, be saviour thou,
My firm ally, for to this land I come
Exile no more ;-on this sepulchral mound
Father I call thee,-hearken to my cry!—
A primal lock, as nurture-gift, I vowed
To Inachos, and now this second lock,
Grief's token, Father, I devote to thee,-
For, absent from thy funeral obsequies,
I could not then as mourner weep thy death,
Nor speed with outstretched hand thy royal bicr.

div.stage: [The Chorus, arrayed in mourning costume, come forth from the palace. ELECTRA closes the procession.]
div.p: But who are these? What means this female train
Conspicuous, in the sable garb of woe?
What may their doleful ministry import?
Doth some new sorrow fall upon our house?
Or do I deem aright that to my sire
They bear libations,-soothings for the dead?
It must be so, for lo, methinks I see,
Steering this way, Electra, my dear sister,
Signal by depth of woe. Oh, grant me, Zeus,
To venge my father's death;-be thou to me
Ally propitious!-Now, my Pylades,
Stand we apart, that I may clearly learn
What may import this suppliant female train.
div.stage: [While the Chorus encircle the tomb, they sing the following Ode.]

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Sent from the palace, forth I tread,
Libations bearing to the dead,
With hands swift-clapped and shrill, a doleful train.
Marred is my cheek with many a gory stain,
Nail-ploughed the new-cut furrows bleed,
The while on sateless cries my heart doth feed.
Rending my flaxen-tissued vest,
With smileless passion, uncontrolled,
Grief doth my sorrow-stricken breast
Dismantle of the garment's decent fold.
For thrilling, ay hair-bristling Fear,
In Atreus' home dream-prophet-seer,
Breathing forth rage in sleep,—at dead of night
From the recesses of these royal halls,
Rang out a cry of wild affright
That heavy on the women's chambers falls.
And dream-interpreters proclaim
Pledged to the truth, in Heaven's name,
That unavenged 'neath earth, the slain
Against their slayers wrathfully complain.
Such graceless grace, against the threatened ill
Devising cure, (oh fostering earth!)
The godless woman sends me to fulfil.
To speak the words prescribed I dread;
For ah! when blood hath once been shed,
Falling to earth, what ransom can be paid?
Woe for the sorrow-stricken hearth,
The home in ruin laid!
By mortals still abhorr'd a cloud,
To sunless darkness wed,
Doth through the master's fall the dwelling shroud.
The majesty invincible of old,
Matchless, supreme, who filled the ear
Of faithful lieges, and their heart controlled,
Standeth aloof;-Fear reigneth now,
For to Prosperity men bow,
Which they as God, ay more than God, revere.
But Justice' stroke some swift doth whelm
In light who dwell elate ;-
While woes from Darkness' glimmering realm
†Lingering on others wait;-
Others sheer Night enshrouds in blackest fate.
When nurturing earth is blood-drenched, lo
Fixed is for aye the vengeance-crying gore ;—
And he who shed it, paying Atè's score,
†Doth burgeon out in all-entangling woe.
The bridal couch if man profane,
†Hopeless is cure;
though in one common flood,
To purify the hand defiled by blood,
All streams commingling flow, they flow in vain.
But for myself, through Heaven's command,
The captured city's doom I share ;-
Led hither from my native land,
'Tis mine the menial's lot to bear.
Their acts, whose will my fortune sways,
Just or unjust, I needs must praise:
†Beneath my vest grief's anguished throes
Shrouding, I quell my bitter hate;-
While numbed in heart by secret woes,
Of my true lords I weep the hapless fate.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Ye captive women, ye who tend this home,
Since ye are present to escort with me
These lustral rites, your counsel now I crave.
How, while I pour these off'rings on the tomb,
Speak friendly words? and how invoke my Sire?
Shall I declare that from a loving wife
To her dear lord I bear them? from my mother?
My courage fails, nor know I what to speak,
Pouring libations on my father's tomb.
Or shall I pray, as holy wont enjoins,
That to the senders of these chaplets, he
Requital may accord, ay! meed of ill.
Or, with no mark of honour, silently,
For so my father perished, shall I pour
These offerings, potion to be drunk by earth,
Then, tossing o'er my head the lustral urn,
(As one who loathed refuse forth has cast,)
With eyes averted, back retrace my steps?
Be ye partakers in my counsel, friends,
For in this house one common hate we share.
Through fear hide not the feelings of your heart;
For what is destined waits alike the free
And him o'ermastered by another's hand;-
If ye have aught more wise to urge, say on.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Thy father's tomb revering as an altar,
Since thou commandest, I will speak my thoughts.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: As thou my father's tomb reverest, speak.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Pour, and high claims uplift for friendly hearts.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Among his friends whom thus may I address?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: First name thyself and whoso hates Ægisthos.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Then for myself and thee pour I this prayer.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Hearing my words, do thou interpret them.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Whom else to number with this friendly band?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Think of Orestes though an exile still.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: 'Tis well,-not vainly hast thou prompted me.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Now for the guilty,—mindful of his death,—

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: What shall I say? unskilled, instruct me thou.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Pray that to them may come or god, or mortal,-

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: As judge or as avenger meanest thou?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Say plainly, who shall death with death requite.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: May I the gods thus pray nor impious be?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: How not requite an enemy with ill?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Of powers above the earth and powers below
Herald supreme, escorter of the shades,
Hermes, now summon to attend my prayer
The guardians of my father's house, dread powers,
Throned in the nether world, and mother Earth,
Who all things bringeth forth, who fosters all,
And doth of all receive again the germ.
And I, libations pouring to the dead,
Thus pray, my Sire invoking;-" Pity me,
And dear Orestes pity;-how shall we
Rule in our palace-home? for sold, alas!
By her who bare us, we as outcasts stray;
While, for Ægisthos, 'complice in thy death,
Her lord she bartered ;-slavish is my lot,
Orestes exiled from his wealth, the while
Revel the twain, exulting in thy fall.
That home Orestes may at length return,
By glad success escorted, I implore.
Give ear, my father, and vouchsafe to me
A spirit than my mother's chaster far,
And hands more pure. For us these orisons;
But for thy foes, may thine avenger come,
And those be justly slain who slaughtered thee.
Thus intermingled with my pious prayer,
For them an evil utterance I pour.
To us upsend these blessings from below,
With gods, and Earth, and Justice conquest-crowned."
Over such prayers, libations, lo! I pour.
Yours be it now, lifting the solemn wail,
To crown with dole the pean of the dead.

div.stage: [While the Chorus sings the following Ode, ELECTRA ascends the steps of the tomb, and pours the libation.]

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: †Drop ye for the dead
Tears with pattering sound;
Lustral rain is shed
O'er the hallowed mound,
From the pure which screeneth bale,
While the powers of Evil quail.
Hear, O master, at thy tomb,
Whispered sounds from sorrow's murky gloom.
Now in measured flow
Tune the notes of woe!
When will warrior brave,
†(War-god strong to save
Houses in the dust laid low,)
Hurl the spear, from hornèd bow
Wing the arrow's deadly flight,
Or wield the hilted brand in closing fight?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: These earth-drained off'rings hath my sire received.

div.stage: [She perceives the lock of hair laid by ORESTES.]
div.p: Ha! this new argument now ponder ye.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: What meanest thou? Boundeth my heart with fear?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: Laid on the tomb this lock of hair I see.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Shorn from what man, or what deep-girdled maid?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: Who here will guess may easily divine.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Although the elder, I from thee would learn.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: There is but one who could have shorn this hair.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: True, foes are they who with the lock should mourn.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: And certes, it is very like in hue.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Like to what tresses? That I fain would learn.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: In sooth it hath the colour of mine own.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Then should it be Orestes' stealthy gift?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: The semblance of his clust'ring locks it bears.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: But hither how could he have dared to come?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.p: He this shorn lock hath sent to grace his sire.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Not less bewept by me what now thou sayest,
If, living, he may never tread this land.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Rolls o'er my heart a surge of bitterness,
Smitten am I as with a piercing shaft;
And from these eyes, while gazing on this lock,
The thirsty drops of sorrow's wintry flood
Flow unrestrained. For how may I conceive
That other of the townsmen owns this hair?
And certes, she who slew him sheared it not,
My mother, all unworthy of the name,
Who towards her children bears a godless mind.
Though not with full assurance may I call
This off'ring his, dearest of mortal men,
Orestes,-still, hope fawns upon my heart.
Alas!—
Oh had it, herald-like, a friendly voice,
So I by doubt no more should be distraught.
Then had it clearly counselled me this lock
To loathe, if severed from a foeman's head,
Or else, akin to me, had shared my grief,
Gracing this tomb, an honour to my sire.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: But let us call upon the gods, who know
In what dire storms, like sailors, we are whirled;
Since if by them our safety is ordained,
From tiny seed may spring a mighty stock.

body.stage: [ELECTRA, descending the steps of the tomb.]

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: And lo, these traces-yet another sign;
Footprints that tally with my own;—and see,
Two diverse outlines are impressed, his own,
And also of some fellow-wayfarer.
The impress of this foot, from heel to toe,
Thus measured, hath the symmetry of mine.
Travails my heart-disordered is my wit.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Acknowledging to Heaven thy prayers fulfilled,
Pray that the further issue may be blest.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: What have I won by favour of the gods?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Him to behold for whom thou long hast prayed.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: How knowest thou for whom I raised the prayer?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: I know Orestes in thy heart enshrined.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: And say wherein are now my prayers fulfilled?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Myself am he;-seck none than me more dear.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Stranger, around me wouldst thou weave some snare?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Myself against myself would then contrive.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Wouldest thou mock at my calamity?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: At mine own grief I mocked, mocked I at thine.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Art thou Orestes? Thou to whom I speak?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Myself thou seest, and discernest not;
Yet gazing on this lock of mourning hair,
And in my footprints marking well my track,
Thy fluttered thoughts did paint me to thine eye.
This lock, thy brother's, like in hue to thine,
Mark well, applying it whence it was shorn;
Mark too this garment, by thy shuttle wrought,
Scenes of the chase, embroidered by thy hand.
Be calm,-through joy lose not thy self-control;
For deadly are, I know, those near in blood.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Oh! cherished darling of thy father's house,
Hope of our race, thou precious seed, long wept,
Trusting in thy strong arm thou shalt regain
Thy natal home. O fondly loved, in whom
Centre four dear affections; for perforce,
Thee I must hail as father, and on thee
Love for my mother, justly hated, falls;
And for my sister, pitilessly slain.
My faithful brother hast thou ever been,
My pride, my awe;-only may Justice, Strength,
With Zeus supreme, third Saviour, aid thy cause.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Zeus, Zeus, beholder be thou of these woes;-
Mark the young brood, reft of their eagle-sire,
Who perished in the folds, the snaky toils
Of direful serpent;-orphaned they endure
The pangs of hunger; not yet strong of wing
To carry to the nest the eagle's prey.
So mayest thou behold us twain, myself,
And her, Electra, offspring sire-bereft,
Thus doomed to common exile from our home.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: And if of sire, who greatly honoured thee
With many a sacrifice, thou slay the brood,
Whence, from like hand, wilt festive gifts obtain?
As none, if thou the eaglets slay, henceforth
To mortals will thy trusty omens bear;
So, if all withered, ne'er this royal stock
On sacrificial days shall aid thy shrine.
Provide; from low estate to greatness lift
A house which verily now prostrate seems.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Oh children, Saviours of your father's hearth,
Forbear, lest some one should o'erhear your words
And all, with gossip-loving tongue, rehearse
To those in power; whom dead I fain would see
Blazing 'mid spirting pine-wood's pitchy brands.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Of Loxias the mighty oracle
Will not betray me; He to this emprize
Hounded me on,-against my inmost reins
Denouncing freezing curses, should I not
Requite the authors of my father's death.
Stript bare and goaded on by forfeiture,
He bade me slay them as my sire they slew,
Declaring I should else atonement make
With my own life and many grievous woes.
First evils dire, from earth that spring, he showed,
Soothing to hostile powers; naming these plagues,—
A leprous canker, cleaving to the flesh,
That eats with rancorous tooth the vital strength,
And through disease blanches the youthful locks;
Next of the Furies other dread assaults
He pictured, springing from my father's blood.
For the dark shafts of those beneath the earth,
(The slain who cry for vengeance to their kin,)
With frenzy wild, and groundless fear at night,
Disturb and harass his distracted soul,
Who clearly in the darkness Phobos sees
To knit his brow. Thus from the town they chase
The wretch all mangled with the brazen scourge.
Moreover to such caitiff is denied
Or festal cup to share, or solemn pledge,
While from the altars, him, a father's wrath
Unseen excludes ;-him may no host receive
To cleanse, with purifying rite, from guilt;—
Till, friendless and dishonoured, dies the wretch,
The shrivelled prey of all-destructive doom;
Such oracles I needs must trust; and e'en
Mistrustful were I, vengeance must be wrought;
For many divers promptings mingle here;—
The god's command, heart-sorrow for my sire,
And indigence hard-pressing: never then
Should citizens, of mortals most renowned,
Who, with heroic spirit, wasted Troy,
Be slaves of women twain. For, sooth, his soul
Is womanish, as trial quick may tell.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Ye mighty Fates, end ye the great emprize,
As Right, with Heaven's high sanction, hath decreed ;-
" Let tongue of Hatred pay back tongue of Hate;"
Thus with her mighty utt'rance Justice cries,
Due penalty exacting for each deed.
" Let murder on the murderous stroke await!”—
"Doer of wrong must suffer."-This sage lore,
Tradition utters, trebly hoar.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: What can I, Sire unblest,
Prayerfully sing,
Thee from thy couch of rest
Hither to wing?
Lo! in that drear confine,
Darkness is day!
Welcome to Atreus' line,
Pour we the lay!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: My son, the wasting jaws of fire
Quell not the spirit of the dead,
Full late he manifests his ire.-
When mourned is he whose blood is shed,
The slayer is revealed. In time,
For slaughtered parents, righteous cry
Of orphans, raised unceasingly,
Availeth to search out the hidden crime.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: In turn, my tearful strain,
O Father, hear!
Hark how thy children twain
Chant anthems drear!
Exiles beside thy tomb,
Sad, suppliant pair ;—
No hope relieves our gloom,
Triumphs despair.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: And yet, should so the god ordain,
Hereafter, gladder notes shall sound;-
Instead of this funereal strain
In palace-halls shall ring amain
A pæan to the dear one newly found.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Oh haddest thou, 'neath Ilion's walls,
But perished, by some Lycian spear
Transfixed, my father, to thy halls
Glory bequeathing, while thy proud career
A lustre o'er the path had shed
Which now in gloom thy children tread;
Beyond the wave, by numbers reared, a mound,
No burthen to thy house, thou then hadst found.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Dear to the dear ones in the fight
Who perished nobly, thou hadst lain,—
With majesty arrayed, and might,
A king in Pluto's gloomy reign,
Serving the great ones who command
In Hades. For in upper day
King was he over kings, whose hand
The fatal sceptre wields which men obey.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Nay, what the need 'neath Ilion's wall
With other victims of the spear,
Father, for thee in death to fall,
And near Scamander grace a foreign bier?
Oh rather might the murderous twain
Themselves have met their death-blow, slain
†By kindred hands, so from afar the tale
Had reached thine ear, shielded thyself from bale.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Richer, my child, thy words than gold;-
Bliss Hyperborean they excel.
†It may not be! Of scourge twofold
The clang resounds.-Already dwell
'Neath earth your champions; they who hold
Loathed empire here have hands unclean.-
On children falls the pang most keen.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Like dart thy word of dread,
Piercing mine ear, hath sped.
Zeus, Zeus, upsending from below
Late thine avenging blow,—
Upon man's daring, crafty deed,
†To parents thou dost deal their righteous meed.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Mine be it, in exultant strain,
To celebrate the howl of pain
From caitiff smitten to the death,
From woman yielding up her breath!
†For why conceal the frenzied throes
That shake my troubled soul?
There blows
At my heart's prow a tempest dire ;-
'Tis rancour's breath, 'tis vengeful ire.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Oh that, with arm of might
Great Zeus, who guards the right,
†Woe, woe, would strike the guilty pair!
Come peace to this domain !
Just meed may the unjust obtain !
Earth, and ye powers of Hades, hear my prayer.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: For law it is, when on the plain
Blood hath been shed, new blood must fall.
Carnage doth to the Fury call;
Avenger of the earlier slain,
She comes, new Ruin leading in her train.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Earth, and ye powers who rule below,
†Behold, and ye dread curses of the slain,
Behold us, outcast, miserable twain,
Poor remnant of the Atridæ;-whither go?
Oh! sov'reign Zeus, what refuge from our woe?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Throbbeth my woman's heart with fear,
The while thy dirge assails mine ear;
At one time hopeful courage wanes,
And darkness o'er my inmost reins
Broods, as I list the doleful sound;
†Then once again my changeful heart,
With hope elate, bids grief depart,
And fair the prospect smileth round.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Can grief by flattery be subdued,
Or soothed by fawning? No, to quell the pain
By parent's hate engendered, charms are vain;
Like savage wolf that ravens for its food,
Tameless from birth is sorrow's torturing brood.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: With Arian beat I strike my breast;
My outstretched hands in wild unrest,
With Kissian mourner's rhythmic woe,
In quick succession,—to and fro,
Shower from all quarters blow on blow;
While with the hurly rings amain
My battered head and my distracted brain.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Cruel, all-daring, Mother, woe!
Alas, as foeman buries foe,
A king, no trusty liegemen near,
Thy wedded lord without a tear,
Thou hadst the heart unwailed to send below.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: All the dishonour thou hast shown:
Therefore shall she our Sire's disgrace atone,
Far as the gods prevail,
Far as my hands avail;
Then may I perish when she lieth prone!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Maimed was he;-let this whet thy hate;
And with like outrage him she did entomb,
That for thy life his fate
Might be too sore a weight.
Such was thy Father's ignominious doom!

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Our Father's lot thy words proclaim;
While I, despised, a thing of nought,
Shut out like vicious cur with shame,
Forgot to smile; alone, I sought
Solace in weeping,-anguish-fraught.
Hearing the tale my lips impart,
Grave it, my brother, on thy inmost heart.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Piercing thine ear, oh may my word
Find access to the depths within!
True is the tale. Thy spirit gird
To hear what yet thou hast not heard!
Now, with undaunted heart the strife begin.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Thine aid, O Father, to thy dear ones lend!

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Weeping sad tears, my voice with his I blend.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Our prayers, in concert, to the shades descend;
Give ear, and rising to the day
Against our foes join thou the fray.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Ares shall cope with Ares,-Right with Right.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Ye gods, give righteous judgment in the fight.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Hearing your prayers, I tremble: hid in night,
Tarries from Eld the doom of Fate;
Invoked it cometh, sure, though late.

sp.speaker: ORESTES and ELECTRA
sp.l: Oh curse that in our house doth reign!
Discordant Atè's murd'rous blow!
Alas intolerable pain!
Alas for cureless woe!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: No foreign aid can bring relief;
No! from yourselves the cure must flow.
'Tis blood must staunch your household grief.
So chant the gods below.

sp.speaker: Chorus-Leader
sp.l: Hear, blessed powers;
Beneath the earth our orisons attend!
And with aspèct benign,
Succour and conquest to the children send!

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: My Father, in no kingly fashion slain,
To me, thy suppliant, grant to sway thy house.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: I too, my Father, need thy gracious aid,
To flee, when wrought is base Ægisthos' doom,

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: So mortal men to thee shall dedicate
The solemn banquet;-else, unhonoured thou,
When grateful reek rich off'rings to the dead.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Nuptial libations of my heritage
I too will bring from the paternal home,
And chief in honour will this tomb adorn.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: O Earth, my sire upsend to watch the fray.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: O Proserpine, grant beautiful success!

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Think, Father, of the bath that reaved thy life.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Think of the net in which they tangled thee.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: In shackles, not of brass, wast thou ensnared.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Basely enveloped in the treacherous folds.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Art thou not roused by these reproaches, Sire?

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: Dost thou not lift erect thine honoured head?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Either send Justice, ally to thy friends,
Or give them in like grasp thy foes to hold,
If thou, o'erthrown, wouldst victor be in turn.

sp.speaker: ELECTRA
sp.l: And hearken, Father, this my last appeal;
Behold thy fledglings nestled on thy tomb;
Pity thy progeny of either sex,
Nor Pelops' remnant seed exterminate;
For in their life thou livest, even in death.
For children are as voices that prolong
The dead man's fame; like corks they float the net,
The flaxen line upbearing from the deep.
Thyself art saved, if thou dost grant our prayer.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Unblamed in sooth have ye your speech prolonged,
Due to his tomb and unlamented fate.
But since to action now thy soul is braced,
To work forthwith! and in the god confide.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: So be it! yet not out of course I ask

div.note: * The story of Meleager, as related by Phoenix to Achilles (Il. ix. 529), is fundamentally opposed to that of the later poets. In Homer nothing is heard of the fatal brand. Meleager had, in some unfortunate fray, killed his mother's brother; upon which his mother solemnly cursed him, and prayed to Pluto and Persephone for his death. At this he was so indignant (or so paralysed for battle by believing in the curse), that he refused to defend his native city, Calydon, at a critical moment, and was only at last prevailed on by his wife to take arms and save it. Here the story ends in Homer; though he says that the Fury who stalks in darkness heard the mother's curse. According to the later poets, Meleager had slain seven brothers of his mother. At his birth she had been informed by the Fates that he would live until a certain log of wood then burning on the hearth was consumed. On this she snatched it off, extinguished it, and kept it carefully in a chest. But now, in rage for the loss of so many brothers, she threw it into the fire, and forthwith her son perished.

Shall we, for Orestes' sake,
Loud the joyous Paan wake?
Hallowed Earth! Oh shrine revered!
Funeral barrow high upreared,
O'er the naval hero-king,
Now give ear, deliv'rance bring!
Strikes the hour;-persuasive Guile
Enters now the lists. The while

sp.speaker: Nurse

sp.speaker: Chorus

sp.speaker: Nurse

sp.speaker: Chorus

sp.speaker: Nurse

sp.speaker: Chorus

sp.speaker: Nurse

sp.speaker: Chorus

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: Nay, with Orestes vanished all our hopes.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.p: Not yet! Dull prophet might interpret here.

sp.speaker: Nurse

sp.speaker: Chorus

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Be it, I go and will obey thy words,
Fair be the issue by the gift of Heaven!

sp.speaker: Chorus

Dispensing justice with omniscient might,
†Bless thou my longing sight!
This boon I crave! Guard him, great Zeus, and save!
Him, in these halls ancestral, place
Before his foeman ;-bring them face to face!
Him if thou lift to greatness, Power divine,
Requital double, triple, shall be thine.
Of him whom thou didst love behold the son
Orphaned, a colt harnessed in sorrow's trace;
†Set thou a limit to his toilsome race!
Grant him his course to run,
With steps firm planted, and well-ordered pace!
You too, frequenting the recess
†Of wealth-rejoicing homes, I now address;
Hear, ye consentient Gods! Through bloody deed
Retributive, wash out the gore,
Dread heirloom from those slain of yore.
Let murder in this palace cease to breed,
When paid the bloody score!
Thou tenant of the cave,-great Spirit,
Give to the hero to inherit
His halls ancestral;-may his eyes,
Fearless and bright,
Peer freely forth from sorrow's veilèd night.
†May Maia's son, well-versed in guile,
Upon the righteous cause propitious smile!
Dark words and subtle speaking, he by night
Men's eyes o'ercloudeth, nor by day
More manifest his secret way.
Yet many a deed, in darkness veiled awhile,
By him is brought to light.
The work achieved, we'll chant the glorious ode;
Our woman's strain,
Propitious, with the mourners' stringed refrain,
Shall ransom this abode.
†Then shall we own the sway of righteous laws,
While Atè from our friends her curse withdraws.
When the fierce business must be done,
When in thine ear she whimpers forth, "My Son;"
Steeling thy heart, recall thy slaughtered sire,
†And cónsummate unblamed the vengeance dire.
With heart of Perseus steadfast in thy breast,
For the dear love
Of friends below the earth, and friends above,
†Complete the sacrifice;—
Within the house plant thou grim Death,-dire guest,-
And let the murderer forfeit murder's price.

sp.speaker: ÆGISTHOS
sp.l: Not uninvoked I come, but hither called;-
For strangers, as I learn, are here arrived,
Bearers of news, unwelcome to our ears,-
Orestes' death, which, charged upon this house,
From former wound still ulcerate and sore,
To me a burden were, dripping with fear.
But say, these tidings must I hold for true,
Or rumours deem them, coined by women's fears,
That aimless cleave the air, and aimless die?
Knowest thou aught that may my mind assure?

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: We have but heard: go thou thyself within.
Question these strangers ;—second-hand reports
Avail not as to hear the tale oneself.

sp.speaker: ÆGISTHOS
sp.l: Fain would I see the messenger and learn
Whether himself was present at the death,
Or if from blind report this tale he heard;
A wakeful mind he will not soon deceive.

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Zeus, great Zeus, how frame my cry
Thine aid to win?
How, invoking thee on high,
My strain begin?
For anon with murderous blow,
Either shall the gory blade
Atreus' royal house o'erthrow,—
Prone in dust for ever laid,—
Or in Freedom's sacred name,
Kindling fire and holy light,
Shall the rightful heir reclaim
†Wealth and crown,-his twofold right.
Sole against the tyrant pair,
To such deadly grapple hies
Agamemnon's godlike heir;-
None to follow if he dies!*
Crown, oh crown, the great emprize!

sp.speaker: ÆGISTHOS
sp.l: Alas, woe's me! Alas!

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: Hark! Hark! again!
How is't? What's wrought within?
Stand we aloof while Slaughter does her work,
Lest we as partners in the deed appear:
For now achieved the issue is of strife.

body.stage: [The Chorus retire to the further side of the tomb.]

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Oh woe! oh grievous woe! our master's slain;
Yet once again, and for the third time, woe.
Ægisthos is no more. With utmost speed
sp.stage: [He knocks at the door of the women's palace.]
sp.l: With crowbars from the hinges heave the doors;
The women's rooms unclose ;-strength need we here,
Not for the slain; what booteth aid to him?
Alas! alas! what, shout I to the deaf,
Or clamour vainly in dull sleepers' ears?
What doeth Clytemnestra? Where is she?
Her neck it seems toucheth the razor's edge;
Herself, ere long shall perish, justly slain.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: What is't? What tumult raise ye in the house?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The dead, I tell you, now the living slays.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Alas! of these dark words the sense I catch;
Through guile we perish, as through guile we slew.
A deadly axe reach hither ;—
sp.p: We shall see
sp.l: Whether I'm vanquished here, or vanquisher;
For to this crisis hath the evil come.

body.stage: [ORESTES and PYLADES come forth from the palace, the door of which remains open.]

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Thee too I seek,-that caitiff hath his due.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Alas! beloved Ægisthos, art thou dead?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Dost love this man? With him, in the same tomb,
Then shalt thou lie ;-still faithful found in death.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Hold! hold! my son ;-Revere, my child, this breast
From which, a sleeping infant, thou full oft,
With toothless gums, thy nurture-milk hast sucked.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Speak, Pylades;-Through filial reverence,
Shall I forbear to shed a mother's blood?

sp.speaker: PYLADES
sp.l: The Pythian oracles, still unfulfilled,
Where are they, and thine own firm-plighted vows?
Choose all for foemen rather than the gods.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Thou hast prevailed; wisely thou promptest me;
So follow;-by his side I thee would slay.
In life thou didst exalt him o'er my sire;
Since him thou lovest, sleep with him in death;
Whom thou wast bound to love thou didst abhor.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: I nourished thee;-with thee I would grow old.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Thou, slayer of my father, dwell with me!

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Fate was, my child, accomplice in these woes.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: And Fate doth now no less thy death ordain.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Dost thou not reverence thy mother's curse?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: My mother, thou didst cast me forth for woe.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Not outcast wast thou in a friendly house.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Sold doubly was I, scion of free sire.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Where then the price for which I bartered thee?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: It shameth me, in sooth, to charge thee home.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: But tell with mine the errors of thy sire.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Sitting at home blame not abroad who toils.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Wretched we women severed from our mates.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: The husband's toil supports the wife at home.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Thy mother, O my child, art nerved to slay?

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Thyself art guilty of thy death, not I.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Take heed, beware thy mother's vengeful hounds.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Those of my sire how 'scape if thee I spare?

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Living, vain moanings to a tomb I pour.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: Ay, for my father's fate doth work thy doom.

sp.speaker: CLYTEMNESTRA
sp.l: Ah me! this man the snake I bare and reared.

sp.speaker: ORESTES
sp.l: True prophet was thy dream-engendered fear.
Him thou didst slay whom thou shouldst not have slain.
So doom unseemly suffer in thy turn.

body.stage: [ORESTES drags his mother into the palace, followed by PYLADES.]

sp.speaker: Chorus
sp.l: F'en of this pair I weep the twofold woe.
But since Orestes hath the bloody height
Achieved of dire revenge, one hope remains,
Not quenched the eye of Atreus' royal house.
As fell at last on Priam's guilty race
The late avenging Fate ;-
A twofold lion now, a twofold Mars
Treads Atreus' halls elate.
Sent from the Pythian shrine
By oracle divine,
Conquest doth now the fugitive await.
Hail jubilant the house redeemed from bale!
The godless pair no more
Shall waste its gathered store.
Hail, joyous riddance, hail!
Requital, guileful power, in stratagem
Dark-veiled who takes delight,
Daughter of Zeus,-Justice yclept by men,
Pointing their aim aright,—
†Doth, with firm hand, the knife
Unsheath for mortal strife;
While 'gainst her foes she breathes destruction's blight.
†For Loxias, the king,
Who in Parnassian cavern holds his seat,
Doth vengeance hither bring,
Guilelessly guileful; lame, yet sure her feet.
Weighty the saying; Zeus, although divine,
No consort is of guilt; needs must we pay
Homage to His heaven-ruling sway.
Clearly the light doth shine!
tReft was I of the sun whose sudden ray
Did with new joy illume
These halls, long sunk in gloom;
It gleamed,—then died away.
†Anon, the cheering light,
New kindled, in this house shall shine once more,
What time, with lustral rite,
From the polluted hearth is purged the gore,
And Atè put to flight. With form benign,
Fortune, long time an alien, comes to claim
Her home, redeemed from shame.
Clearly the light doth shine!

div.note: * ”Εφεδρος, an antagonist in reserve. The Chorus uses the technical language of wrestlers in the games.

div.head: NOTES.
CHOEPHORI.
div.p: 56. For μένει χρονίζοντ᾽ ἄχη βρύει read μένει χρονίζοντας ἄχη, omitting βρύει.
61. For παναρκέτας νόσου βρύειν read παγκαρτέρας νούσου βρύειν.
65. For ἐκ μίας ὁδοῦ I conjecture ἐκ [τρικυ]μίας ὁμοῦ; also omit the prosaic τὸν before χερομυσῆ.
67. For καθαίροντες ἰοῦσαν ἄτην, perhaps καθαίροντες [καθαίρ] ουσιν μάτην.
68-72 and 73-77 to be also antistrophic; but here dwell only on the changes important to a translator.

In 73, for βίαι φερομένων read βίαια φυρωμένων, and in 71, 72 read— [δεῖ] δίκαια, μὴ δίκαια, [μὴ] πρέποντα and for ἀρχαῖς βίου, which is unintelligible, the least correction is ἀρχαῖσί μου; yet I suspect that the poet wrote ἀκριβέσι, "exact in virtue."

145-156. Read ἀπότρεπον for ἀπότροπον, governing accus. ἄχος, and join κεδνῶν with ἀπότρεπον. Then τ' after κεδνῶν must be omitted or changed to γ'. In v. 150 σεβασω is clearly corrupt. We need a tribrach, beginning with two consonants, to support the ε of κλύε. I conjecture σκεπανὰ, “ things covered.” Besides, καναχές, " tinkling as metal,” is an improbable epithet of a tear. The line has no metre. Aldus edited κἀναχες, which suggests to me κἀναχεῖτ'. Ὀλόμενον
is also an unpleasant epithet, especially as joined with ὀλομένῳ δεσπότα. I incline to put ὀλόμενον in brackets.

155. "Αρης in that position cannot be right. I think it should be μάχης. A verb is deficient. One may think of ἐπιπάλλοι μάχης for ἐπιπάλλων ἄρης. In that case ἂν may well be supplied before ἀναλυτήρ, since τίς ἂν with the optative expresses “Oh that!” I further think that χεροῖν παλίντονα ἐν should be κεροῖν παλιντόνοιν, since bows and not arrows are παλίντονα. Perhaps the piece is antistrophic, and some further errors may thus be discerned.
271. τάσδε νῶν.— By all means adopt Hermann's τάσδ' αἰνῶν.

361. The word ὤφελον is essential. We may read πάρος δ' [ὠφελόν γ'] οἱ κτανόντες νιν οὕτω δαμῆναι. if in the strophe, 343, we read τέκνων τ᾽ ἂν κελεύθοις ἐπίστρεπτον ἀιῶ κομίσσας. v.e., τ' ἂν for re, and κομίσσας for κτίσσας, which make good metre.
366. For ὀδυνασαι I think οὐ δύνασαι is far better than δύνασαι.

613. For ἀκαίρως δὲ I suggest Ἀχαιοίς γε, as expressing at least the right syntax and general sense. For ἀπεύχετον by all means read ἀπευκτέον with Blomfield. Next, for σέβας τιων δὲ read σεβαστέον δὲ, and the sentence as a whole will be clear. Only ἐπικότῳ remains corrupt. The emphasis of Clytemnestra's guilt will be marked by δῄοις ὑπερκότῳ, triumphant over the foe;” as in Agam. 795, ὑπερκότους, "triumphant, successful." (Whether the true spelling be ὑπέρκοπος does not here concern us.)

633. A verb is lost, to which παρεκβάντες is nominative, For γὰρ οὐ λὰξ perhaps γὰρ [ὤλεσαν] λὰξ: οὐ makes sheer nonsense. Πατρὸς is also deficient in the antistrophe. For † διμασε αἱμάτων perhaps δόμοισι [τοῖς πατρὸς, χ], αἱμάτων, which will fulfil the metrical conditions.
715. τὸν Νύχιον is not explicable. I think some one has well suggested τὰν Νυχίαν, “ the Fury, Child of Night,” Eumen. 311.
773, 774. Read—δὸς τύχας πλεῖν δόμοις κυρίως, πανσόφῳ σθένει μαιομένα σ' ἰδεῖν διαδικάσαι.
783. For ἐν δρόμῳ προστιθεὶς read κἀν δρόμῳ προστιθείης.
784, 785. Read (as a first approximation)— δὸς οὖν σωζομένου ῥυθμοῦ ποτε διαθεῖν ἔμπεδον ἀνόμενων βημάτων ὄρεγμα.
788. By all means retain νομίζετε.
791. I think λύσασθ' should be λύσαιθ', addressed to the gods.
793. For τὸ δὲ καλῶς κτάμενον read τοῦδε καλῶς κταμένου, or τοῖνδε καλῶς κταμένοιν, and so end the third strophe.
794. εὖ δὸς ἂν ἰδεῖν is certainly corrupt, especially as ἰδεῖν is in the next line. Σὺ δ᾽ ἀμφιεπεῖν . . . is possible, or σὺ δ᾽ ἄρ᾽ ἀμφιεπεῖν. After λαμπρῶς perhaps δὸς is wanting.
799. For ἐπιφορώτατος read ὁ φωριώτατος.
801. For κρύπτ᾽ ἄσκοπον δ' read κρύφα μὲν, εὔσκοπον δ'.
802. For νύκτα πρό τ', . . read νύκτωρ πρὀυμμάτων.

803. For ἐμφανέστερος read with Schutz ἐμφανέστερον. In place of πολλὰ δ᾽ ἄλλα φανεῖ χρήζων, which comes out of place after 800, I think we should have, to close antistrophe 3, πολλά τε δῆλα φανεῖ. The superfluous χρήζων rises out of the error that Apollo, not Mercury, is intended.
805. For τοτε δὴ read τότ' ᾠδὰν, κλυτὸν for πλοῦτον, λύτρον for λυτήριον, and leave σχέθων in 817 unchanged.
811. Read μεθήσομεν πόλει. τὸ δ' εὔνομον ἐμοὶ κέρδος αὔξεται, τοι τὸ δ' εὖ ἐμὸν ἐμὸν κέρδος ἀέξεται.
815. περαίνων. Adopt Blomfield's πέραιν' οὐκ.
820. For προπράσσων χάριτος ὀργὰς λυπρὸς read πρόπραξον χάριν σφαγᾶς λυτῆρος, as at least something possible.
823. φοινίαν, read φόνιον.
824. ἐξαπολλὺς μόρου cannot be right. Perhaps ἐξαπόλλυ ἐν μέρει, “ in turn, in retaliation.”
849. After πολισσονόμους add with Hermann [πλοῦτόν τε δόμων].
935. For ἔθιγε δὲ μάλα, or δὲ μάχα, we need δὲ ξίφους. The scholiast has ἐφήψατο τοῦ ξίφους.

940—947. This third strophe is terribly corrupt. For τάνπερ I propose τάδ' ἄρα; in ἐποχθείαξεν I see ἀπαξιῶν, τὰν έ being written χο in very old style. Τὰν is essential with δολίαν. For βλαπτομέναν I propose βλαψίπουν (pede l'œna claudo); I leave ἐν χρόνοις as it is, but for θεῖσαν ἐποίχεται I conjecture οἷσι μετοίχεται, " fetches in his own tines.” Then 944, κρατεῖται πως should be κρατεῖ τοι λόγος, or φάτις (see Pers., 724; Suppl., 290; Soph. Αj., 978). For τὸ θεῖον παρὰ τὸ read τὸ, θεῖόν περ ὄντα, and add [Δία] after ὑπουργεῖν. Sense and metre are then perfect, except that we may read μὴ οὐκ for μὴ to remedy hiatus. Δὲ after ἄξιον must be retained.

948. The second antistrophe begins μέγαν τ' ἀφηρέθην ψάλιον οἴκων ἄναγε μὰν δόμοις. I propose μέγαν ἀφηρέθην ἅλιον, οἰκίοις | ἀναφανέντ᾽ ἐμοῖς : the Sun being " prosperity from the prince's face.” Next, with Elmsley, χαμαιπετὴς ἔκειτο. But a line is defcient. Perhaps ἀεὶ [καλυφθεὶς σκότῳ], which completes sense and metre.
952. For χρόνος ἀμείψεται perhaps χρόνῳ σκέψεται, or χρόνοις σκέψεται. The verb should at least be a Cretic foot.
954. For μύσος πᾶν ἐλάσῃ I would read μῦσος ἅπαν παραλύσῃ, for metrical reasons, and because of ἀτᾶν ἐλατηρίοις following.
958. For ἰδεῖν ἀκοῦσαι θρεομένοις, perhaps ἰδεῖν ἀκοῦσαί τ' ἐραμένοισιν.

1058. μόχθοι τάλανές τε Θυέστου is clearly wrong. One cure is to omit τε Θυέστου, regarding Θυέστου to be an interpretation, and Te to have been inserted afterwards for the metre. If Θυέστου must be retained, we need something like πίνακές (the dishes) for τάλανές; or if τάλαρος, like calathus may mean a dish, τάλαροί will be as plausible.
F. W. N.
